titlepage.title: Malleus Deum
titlepage.subtitle: Igitur qui desiderat pacem, praeparet bellum.
titlepage.author: Blaize A. Rhodes
William F. Rhodes

section.p: This game has the following design goals:

li.p: The authors believe that the big name RPGs are showing their age. Dungeons and Dragons is now 40 years old. While there are a large number of indie rpgs that have explored interesting new rpg design elements, Dungeons and Dragons has remained relatively static, its development ossified by negative feedback to changes from its large existing fan-base. These rules represent a response to this state of affairs.

Malleus Deum is an attempt at a modern rule set. It tries to integrate advances in RPG rule design into an otherwise traditional RPG rules system. Specifically we try to include an Aspect-like mechanic from FATE, linear magic-users like 13th age and Dnd5e, a strategic initiative phase from Dr Who to encourage non-combat resolutions, simple unified resolutions, morale, and adding benefits and complications to dice results.

In this game we are trying to deemphasize combat. Not remove it. But take an opportunity to try and provide rules that will allow the GM to shine the light on other parts of the game: negotiation, morale, fleeing and pursuit, investigation and personal development.

It's nice to have a change in pace and scenery. We have tried to design a game where combat plays a major role, but other aspects of the game, such as role-playing, negotiation, non-lethal combat, and investigation, are also a possibility.

We feel it is important for users of the game that the game license allow people to contribute to the game on their own terms and have, therefore, released the game under the Creative Commons Attribution License 3.0, which is available online. In a nutshell, you are free, to:
Share — to copy, distribute and transmit the work, to
Remix — to adapt the work, and to
Make commercial use of the work
Under the following conditions:
Attribution — You must attribute the work in the manner specified by the author, but not in any way that suggests that they endorse you or your use of the work.
All creative commons licenses require attribution. We suspect it may have something to do with establishing the provenance of the license.

Modular and Customizable: Our goal is that you should be able to include the bits you want, exclude the bits you do not, customize whatever you like, add whatever house rules you like, then build your own set of rule books and modules and print them.
Modularity also makes maintaining balance in an evolving game easier as some parts of the system can be tweaked without effecting other parts.

Moderately heavy-weight rules complexity means that the rules are a little more complicated than, for example, FATE, FUDGE, Basic Dnd, or Call of Cthulhu and a little less complicated than say DnD4e. Combat needs to be easy enough that GMs can throw challenging encounters together on the fly. But the rules for character progression need to be rich enough to capture and keep the imagination of the players.

Geared to a low magic setting. At high level magic becomes difficult to GM with a myriad of unforeseen interactions and unintended consequences. In the authors opinion, there are also problems with game balance in high fantasy settings. As George Martin said: ``If you look at The Lord of the Rings, what strikes you, it certainly struck me, is that although the world is infused with this great sense of magic, there is very little onstage magic. So you have a sense of magic, but it's kept under very tight control.''. We also refer the interested reader to Sandersons Rules of Magic.
Malleus Deum is designed specifically for fantasy settings. We feel that generic role playing systems do not fit any milieu particularly well - they are the jacks of all trades and masters of none.

We hope to develop this game via a process of gradual incremental improvement. There is a constraint on the corporate model of RPG development where each new version of the rules has to be significantly different from previous versions otherwise they cannot justify the prices they charge for the new books or resell you the same modules. An open source model has no such constraints. We hope that an open approach will allow a slow process of identifying problem areas with the rules and fine-tuning those rules in a slow and incremental process.

The default milieu for the game draws elements from the standard fantasy sources: Lord of the Rings, Conan the Barbarian, Dungeons and Dragons, and Warhammer and also some slightly unusual sources: Jim Butchers Dresden Files, Charles Stross's Laundry Files and Lovecraft.

section.p: We hope you enjoy the game.

Good game design requires a balanced mechanical foundation. In this chapter we lay out the design principles we use to try to ensure compelling game play and good game balance. In later sections we will apply those principles to individual game mechanics.

subsection.p: We do not believe that complex game mechanics are necessary for good gameplay. Keeping the number and complexity of the game mechanics of the game small makes for a faster, easier and more enjoyable game to play.

principle.label: Simplicity
principle.principlebody: Keep the number of mechanics to a minimum.

subsection.p: Behavioural psychology, and more specifically, operant conditioning, suggests that the best training schedule is one with random positive reinforcement and not continuous feedback. What that means in English is that random stepped increases in player character advancement is ``more fun'' than gradual continuous improvement or improvement at fixed times.

principle.label: Random Reinforcement
principle.principlebody: Character progression should increase in large and infrequent semi-random discrete steps, and not gradually.

subsection.p: It has been claimed that a well designed game presents players with problems that force them to make interesting decisions. Game Theory has the concept of a dominant strategy. If a problem has a dominant strategy then there is a solution to that problem that is clearly better than all the rest. If a game has problems have dominant strategies then they are not forcing players to make interesting decisions.

principle.label: Avoid Dominant Strategies
principle.principlebody: We should strive to provide choices to players that do not have any clearly better general-purpose solution when creating, developing and playing his character. Force the characters to make meaningfull choices.

subsection.p: Let us define the playable range for standard check dice mechanics to be the range of values that have a probability from, say, 30 to 80. This represents the range that most but not all checks should be in to make for an interesting game.

If players have more than an 80 chance of succeeding, then play becomes a little too easy and monotonous. If players have less than a 30 chance of succeeding then play becomes frustrating. This range is a little arbitrary but good enough for the purposes of this discussion.

principle.label: Playable Range
principle.principlebody: Checks have a playable range which is not too hard and not too easy. Most checks in the game should fall in the playable range.

subsection.p: Furthermore, experience suggests that, on the whole, players prefer to succeed in their checks more than they fail, by which we mean that the typical probability of success should be in the range 50-70.

principle.label: Succeed more than you Fail
principle.principlebody: On average, checks should succeed more often than fail.

subsection.p: We will steal an idea from DungeonWorld and Numenera and make players roll for defence when they are being attacked. This will keep them busy and engaged and free up time for the GM.

The character archetypes should feel different to play and have strengths and weaknesses to provide variety and tactical options during game play. For the purposes of discussion we can break the archetypes into four groups: Tanks, Damagers Support (Controllers, Healers, etc) and Generalists.

We expect that the Tanks should be more defensive than the other classes, the Damagers should do more damage. Support should be sub-optimal in the damaging and defense roles but have additional strategic and/or buffing options available to them during combat.
The Generalists are specialized non-combatants. We introduce them because we are trying to deemphasize combat. At the same time we want the generalists to have reasonable options within combat and be able to be reasonably effective otherwise combat is boring for these archetypes. To this end it is important that the generalists performance in combat is worse than that of the combat specialists, but not drastically so. We need to define an envelope within which there is a difference between combat ability, but that difference is not so great that the generalists feel left out of combat.

principle.label: Archetype Differentiation
principle.principlebody: Archetypes should be either specialists, strong in one area and weak in others or generalists that are somewhat competent in combat.

subsection.p: We will give monsters a very similar combat classification to those used by Dnd 4e as it introduces a nice level of strategy to combat. Each monster has a level and a combat role: Grunt, Brute, Soldier, Artillery, Elite, Skirmisher, Lurker, or Elite. In addition they can have a hybrid role, i.e. Solo, Controller, or Leader that augments their role in combat.

subsection.p: The hybrid roles include the following:

descriptions.description: have the same kinds of abilities as their PC analogs. They are able to buff their side, or debuff their opponents, allow their allies to move unhindered across the battlefield, etc.

Solos are monsters that can fight a party of adventurers on their own. They have similar AC to the Grunts but a lot more HP, they do a lot more damage and they should have multiple attacks and possibly special abilities.

subsection.p: To make it easy to compare monster and PC strengths monsters and characters of the same level should have similar AC and do similar damage. Monsters will typically have fewer HP.

section.subsection:
Standard Checks
It follows from PrincipleSucceed more than you Fail that for standard checks, such as to-hit rolls, there is a finite range of values within the 2d12 or 2-24 range that are reasonable and enjoyable to choose for difficulty values.
{% include "docs/tables/probabilities_2d12.xml" %}
To Hit Probabilities 2d12 vs d20 figure:tohit2d12vsd20
Based on the following graph, see Figurefigure:tohit2d12vsd20 and Tabletable:probabilities_2d12, we can see that the playable range, with a success rate of 30-80 for a 2d12 mechanic is about 11 to 18 with a difference of 7. The playable range for 1d20 is 7 to 17 with a difference of 10. It follows that bonuses to Std Checks, must be smaller than equivalent bonuses in a d20 system, a +2 bonus in a d20 system like DnD is roughly equivalent to a +3 bonus in a 2d12 system. A +4 bonus in a d20 system is roughly equivalent to a +5 bonus in a 2d12 system.
Std Checks Bonuses should be at most +4 Bonuses for Std Checks should be at Most +4
Because the 2d12 checks have a smaller playable range than d20 systems the maximum, unadjusted, difference for a standard check bonus between any two archetypes at the same level should be less than or equal to +4.
Note that the average result for 2d12 is also higher, 13 in our 2d12 system versus 10.5 in a d20 system.

Dice Pools
Dice pool mechanics are used for a number of different things Magic, Mettle, and Luck. Here we take a quick look at dice pool behaviour. In Table dicepools we provide a range of difficulties (and overcharge values for spells). Assuming that dedicated first level spell casters can cast a few spells before replenishing their dice pools it follows, from Table figure:dicepools, that their dice pools should contain about 2 to 3 dice which will allow them to cast six to nine difficulty 3 spells. Further, suppose we wish a 10th level caster to be able to cast a similar number of difficulty 14 spells, then their dice pool size should be about 6 to 9 dice.

subsection.p: To-Hit rolls are basically a kind of Std Check. Consequently, the same narrower playable range applies to the to-hit rolls of different classes. We aim to have a reasonable small difference in combat ability between generalist classes and combat specialist classes in Malleus Deum. It would seem that in order to have the generalist characters be able to enjoy combat the to-hit bonus difference between generalists and combat specialists should be no more than 3 for characters of the same level.

figure.caption: PC To Hit Bonus by Level
figure.label: figure:to_hit_bonus_by_level

subsection.p: For a typical monster of the samel level PC Combat classes should hit on average two in three times. Non combatants should hit ever slightly less frequently. Monster armour classes then flow from the desired hit ratio and the PC per level to hit table.

We can choose the amount of damage PCs deal fairly arbitrarily and scale other game mechanics accordingly (such as monster and PC hit points). The base damage for a weapon is d8. Weapons that do d10 should be two handed. Weapons that do d6 should have other advantages, eg they can be thrown, are easy to learn, can be concealed about ones person, etc. We want to make the choice of weapons an actual choice, no dominant strategy, so there cannot be a best weapon.
We will also adopt the damage scaling system from 13th Age. At certain levels, we will increase the number of dice rolled for damage.

In order to balance play we have the following set of rules of thumb to allow us to maintain game balance. Characters that deal average damage should be able to kill a Grunt of their level with two average hits. Non-combat specialist characters should be able to kill a monster in two or three average hits.

Monster attack difficulties should be roughly equivalent to player characters attack difficulties of the same level. However players roll to hit and we want a single target number of monster to hit difficulties so we will take the monster to-hit difficulties from the average of the player to hit rolls. See Figurefigure:monster_attack_difficulty_by_level for monster attack difficulties.

Defense checks are made by players to avoid being hit by monsters. The most common defense checks are Armour, Dodge, Block and Parry Checks. Based on the following graph it seems that in order to have the generalist characters able to enjoy combat the to-hit difference between generalists and combat specialists should be no more than 2. Monster damage for a typical Grunt should be one par for a player character of the same level (it makes the maths easy), see Figure figure:pc_avg_dmg_by_level.

In order to make combat sufficiently dangerous while still mitigating the effect of a few lucky roles on monster attacks we decide that a PC should be able to survive between four and six hits from a typical monster of the same level. To simplify matters we can require that a typical monster does the same amount of damage as the character of the same level.

principle.principletitle: PCs should be able to take 4-6 hits.
principle.label: PCs should be able to take 4-6 hits.
principle.principlebody: Most PCs should have enough hit points to sustain four hits from an average monster of their level. Tanks should have enough hit points to sustain six.

subsection.p: An average level skill should cost 5 skill points.

If skills require successes/attempts then they must have a Check defined. The check should include a DDC. If the check uses a dice pool the ability should also have an overcharge value. The overcharge should be a value relative to the DC used .. e.g. DC + 5.

principle.label: No Dominant Strategy
principle.principlebody: There should not be a dominant strategy for any particular character.

principle.label: Meaningful Difference
principle.principlebody: Character archetypes should be sufficiently different from one another.

subsection.p: Abilities should have a type and a level so that we can make make archetypes different and so we can make the players make meaningfull choices when developing their characters.
